event_entry¶

Accessor to the related object on the forward side of a many-to-one or one-to-one (via ForwardOneToOneDescriptor subclass) relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

Child.parent is a ForwardManyToOneDescriptor instance.

class events.models.Congress(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: django.db.models.base.Model

A specific congress including year

We set all values to be optional so we can use the wizard format and save partial data as we go. The validation for completeness of data lies in the view.

congressdownload_set¶

Accessor to the related objects manager on the reverse side of a many-to-one relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

Parent.children is a ReverseManyToOneDescriptor instance.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager class built by create_forward_many_to_many_manager() defined below.

class events.models.CongressMaster(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: django.db.models.base.Model

Master List of congresses. E.g. GCC. This is not an instance of a congress, just a list of the regular recurring ones. Congresses can only belong to one club at a time. Control for who can setup a congress as an instance of a congress master is handled by who is a convener for a club

exception DoesNotExist¶

Bases: django.core.exceptions.ObjectDoesNotExist

events.views module¶

events.views.admin_summary(request, congress_id)[source]¶

Admin View

events.views.checkout(request, congress_id=None)[source]¶

Checkout view - make payments, get details

events.views.create_congress_wizard(request, step=1, congress_id=None)[source]¶

create a new congress using a wizard format.

There are a number of steps. Step 1 creates a congress either from scratch or by copying another one. All other steps edit data on the congress. The last steps allows the congress to be published.

events.views.create_congress_wizard_1(request, step_list)[source]¶

congress wizard step 1 - create

events.views.create_congress_wizard_2(request, step_list, congress)[source]¶

wizard step 2 - general

events.views.create_congress_wizard_3(request, step_list, congress)[source]¶

wizard step 3 - venue

events.views.create_congress_wizard_4(request, step_list, congress)[source]¶

wizard step 3 - sponsor

events.views.create_congress_wizard_5(request, step_list, congress)[source]¶

wizard step 5 - options

events.views.create_congress_wizard_6(request, step_list, congress)[source]¶

wizard step 6 - events

events.views.create_congress_wizard_7(request, step_list, congress)[source]¶

wizard step 7 - publish

events.views.delete_congress(request, congress_id)[source]¶

delete a congress

Parameters

  • request (HTTPRequest) – standard user request

  • congress_id (int) – congress to delete

Returns

redirects to events

Return type

page(HTTPResponse)

events.views.enter_event_form(event, congress, request)[source]¶

build the form part of the enter_event view. Its not a Django form, we build our own as the validation won’t work with a dynamic form and we are validating on the client side anyway.

events.views.home(request)[source]¶
events.views.view_congress(request, congress_id, fullscreen=False)[source]¶

basic view of an event.

Parameters

  • request (HTTPRequest) – standard user request

  • congress_id (int) – congress to view

  • fullscreen (boolean) – if true shows just the page, not the standard surrounds

  • accepts a GET parameter of msg to display for returning from event entry (Also) –

Returns

page with details about the event

Return type

page(HTTPResponse)
